title: Power and Sample Size in R
text:
Preface
This is a Quarto book.
To learn more about Quarto books visit https://quarto.org/docs/books.

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: 1  One or two means
text:
1.1 Example 3.2
We plan to measure hemoglobin A1c in a sample of 36 patients and conduct a lower-tailed test at \(\alpha = 0.05\) of
\[
H_0: \mu\ge5.7 \quad \text{versus} \quad H_A: \mu<5.7
\]
If true value of \(\sigma\) is 2 and true population mean is 4.9, what is the power?
library(powertools)
ttest.1samp(N = 36, delta = 4.9 - 5.7, sd = 2, alpha = 0.05, 
            power = NULL, sides = 1)

[1] 0.7606311
The power is about 0.76
power.t.test(n = 36, delta = 5.7 - 4.9, sd = 2, sig.level = 0.05, 
             type = "one.sample", alternative = "one.sided")


     One-sample t test power calculation 

              n = 36
          delta = 0.8
             sd = 2
      sig.level = 0.05
          power = 0.7606311
    alternative = one.sided
